In 1968 I did research to try to put a machine, a molecular beam, on a glass slide, that could then be rotated to get three way velocity specification. The microchip etching needed had not yet been invented (I tried to use asphalt and HF). But there were mechanical components too. These kind of etchable devices could serve for controls. So far as I know, the device has never been made or researched. Maybe it's time to try again using these advanced mechanisms.

I suppose one of the earliest examples of a simple compliant device that I was introduced to, was at college, in the 70's.
It was an example of a real problem solved.
An aircraft had a self starter, but the shaft was inclined to shear, due to the inertia of the large engine, and the necessary rather ferocious torque of the starter motor.
So the shaft was made bigger, and it still broke!
So it was made bigger still, but it still broke!
Then another engineer got involved, and instead of making it bigger, he made it smaller, so it acted like a spring torsion bar.
It stopped breaking!
I solved a problem with a ''fruit machine,'' also known as a ''one armed bandit!''
The reel stops were controlled by a lever operated by a solenoid.
In order for the lever to release, it had to be spring loaded.
This required pins, and springs, to produce a two way sliding mechanism.
From memory, I think sixteen pieces total.
I replaced it with THREE, by using a piece of flexible 'memory foam,' which also provided damping.😊

Centrifugal Clutch on my old go cart (driven wheel) had a cylindrical aluminum housing. Driving through the woods one day, caught a branch in the chain sprocket. I surmised turning the wheel in reverse could free it, but more leverage if I could spin the clutch body & sprocket to release the branch. My bare thumb & fore-finger slid off the clutch housing with a sizzle, so fast that it didn’t hurt, but the white char endured for a while (no scar remained), but lesson learned.

Have to stop you at "a million cycles." I will never forget this claim from when plastic door hinges and tool boxes came out many decades ago.

It wasn't long until we started to see failures.

For one thing, they aren't cycled continuously. Maybe the heat that generates makes the hinges more flexible or tougher.

But it also doesn't account for the leaching or of plasticizers over time, which makes the material more brittle and prone to fatigue.

Of course, plastics have improve since the 1960s, but the test method depicted was the same.

Interesting video, but badly titled. What you mean is "flex" , not "bend". The two are opposites, not equals.

"Flex" is when an object changes shape due to application of force, but when the force is removed, the object returns to its original shape. (Example: Leaf or coil springs in suspensions of cars.) Synonym for "flex": "compliance".

"Bend" is when an object changes shape due to application of force, but when the force is removed, the object does not resume its previous shape, but rather, maintains its new shape. (Example: making metal "L" brackets by bending flat strips of metal in a metal bender.) Synonym for "bend": "deformation".

Look-up "Hooke's Law" and "elastic limit" in Wikipedia for much more on this. (Hint: an object "flexes" until it's elastic limit is reached, then it "bends".)

Important in biology. The human foot is a wonderful compliant mechanism in that it allows erect (bipedal) walking to require little energy compared to four-footed walkingrunning. That is why Louis Leakey was able to learn from the Kikuyu in Kenya how to outrun antelopes. He claimed that people have greater stamina. But in reality, the compliant mechanism in the human foot conserves energy better than the four feet of the antelope. Since human conserve energy when walking and running, they can run down antelopes. We conclude that muscles and tendons are compliant mechanisms.

I would think this video is a bit misleading no?  Really only plastics and other flexible materials can be used as far as I am concerned (not too familiar on plastics).  But this certainly would not be good for metal applications. Metals are known to fall victim to metal fatigue. For example, chains have zero moving parts and zero bending parts. However, chains have been known to spontaneously fail below their specified rates, and they have zero moving and bending parts. I couldn't imagine something like that titanium hinge falling under the same circumstances, and probably even worse because of the bending crystal structure. Although its great if its not being used a lot (if that's what NASA intended).

3:50] "Over a million cycles," in the fatigue testing. Not bad. Really. I have a plethora of... locking pliers, [to avoid using a trade-name] some of them over thirty years old, they work exactly as originally manufactured as hard as I have beaten on them. Now imagine pairing one of these extruded-bread-loaf-plastic 'vicy-grips' with the threads of a grade-8 bolt corrosion welded into an engine block? When a tool is materially much less tough than the work it will fail almost immediately. The toughness of the machine must be matched to the toughness of what it works on, such that the machine is much tougher that the work. Place for compliant machines? yeah, no doubt, but you have to match the machine to it's work rather precisely.

Put four centrifuge clutches of different sizes in a row for use in an automatic shiftless transmission. Each engaged at a certain RMP while the one below it which is smaller deactivated just past the time the second one engaged. Let off the accelerator and there is no drag because all clutches disengage due to lack of RPM. You could engage drag if you needed help stopping so when you hit the brakes it would switch on drag from any locations you desired in the mechanical system that makes it go or stop.

Impressive. I'm just fascinated that these parts which act like hinges & are formed in plastic are capable of sustaining such an incredible number of bend cycles. Even more interesting is that the same methodology is capable of working in such diverse materials as plastic, silicon & titanium.

This is Exactly the kind of technology which should be introduced through STEM courses - the younger, the better. Have kids
3-D print out components for robots, or a R/C Car, or whatever & get them stimulated, creative, involved, etc.

I love seeing the joy as I watch these two professional science YouTubers (one an actual physicist) playing with these things. 😁

My brain's popping with so many applications... ; )~
• Take that Gripping Tool & (just for the hell of it) extent the arms... ...a lot... What pressures could you get with 1, 2, 5, 10, etc. metre long arms?
• Imagine a Bike Wheel using a similar hinge design to the Dumbo, but where the centered component was the axle. You could have a wheel which adapted it's outer ring contour to the environment, warping over & around a rock or fallen log (instead of stiffly rotating over & around it, before impacting with gravity) as the wheel passes across it. Simultaneously, it would keep the axle at a fixed distance to the ground, making for a very smooth ride - even off-road.
• Childproof Drawers which have microplastic switches built into the frame (like lift/elevator doors). Any obstruction - such as tiny fingers - would press a switch, which in turn would trigger a braking system - well before injury.
• Cooling Fan Blades (for computers, housing, people) which rotate to change their angle based on their speed (improving efficiency & reducing noise), instead of just being fixed.
• Alternatively, for small scale Wind Generator/Water Turbines.
• 3-D Print a prosthetic hand with a single plastic body including joints (& with cavities, guide tubes for motors, servor & cables, etc.).

~ ~ ~

Materials science & mechanical engineering are definitely beginning to move towards the Singularity...

why doesn't the hole at the end of the elephant's trunk move ?

because said hole is located at the lower left corner of a (not-immediately-obvious) parallelogram
whose four vertices are located at the following points :
A) the hinge point at the elephant's back hip
B) the hinge point at the elephant's back foot
E) the hinge point at the elephant's jaw and
Q) the hole at the end of the elephant's trunk.

this parallelogram is divided into two contiguous smaller parallelograms side-by-side.

the rightmost smaller parallelogram has vertices at these points :
A) the hinge point at the elephant's back hip
B) the hinge point at the elephant's back foot
C) the hinge point at the elephant's front hip and
D) the hinge point at the elephant's front foot.

the leftmost smaller parallelogram has vertices at these points :
C) the hinge point at the elephant's front hip
D) the hinge point at the elephant's front foot
E) the hinge point at the elephant's jaw and
Q) the hole at the end of the elephant's trunk.

the "virtual" line segments EQ and BQ which meet at point Q
are constrained to exist (geometrically)
by the structural elements which are present physically.

Такой вот привет из роддома, о котором не ставят почему то в известность родителей!
После этого мне стало интересно, и я сделал МРТ головы ( для начала, так как стоимость процедуры не дешевая) и обнаружил радио имплантат возле правого уха, который как я понимаю имплантировали мне в роддоме, и это не голоса это чувства, так как идет непрерывная работа по нервной системе! Система такая, об этом ни кто не должен был знать, но под контролем власти хотят держать каждый мозг! Объяснение простое, система хочет что бы все на неё работали, она не хочет что бы каждый развивался и становился автономной частью! К врачам безполезно обращаться так как их не специализировали в таких технологиях и тайных проделках системы, вам не помогут не психиатры ни психологи ни психотерапевты ни остальные прочие, только выявлять металлоискателем имплантированные места на теле самостоятельно и настоятельно брать направление к хирургу на операцию, типа у вас там киста или фиброма или ещё что то! Такие вот делишки. Система не хотела отпускать меня в частный сектор из города!

The nuclear weapon device is almost exactly like the motor drive for HO slot cars in about 1960. It was a reed that vibrated against a ratchet wheel. The vibration of the reed was due to resonant vibration induced by an electromagnet driven by 60hz voltage. We had all kinds of fun adjusting the reeds and modifying the grooves in the ratchet wheel.
However we did not experiment with a non 60 Hz source. I would figure that a non 60Hz voltage applied to the reed would not successfully vibrate it unless it met the natural fundamental resonance of the reed. If we could have tuned the frequency of the AC voltage I would suspect we could have sped up the cars immensely. However, we could already tune them up to the point that they couldn't make the corners and go flying off the table. But it would have been even more fun to make them fling across the room.
In this sense it you made the vibrating reed to be resonant with only a fairly precise frequency plus heavily damped then external vibration could not move it and only the exact frequency could. Thus making it a fairly safe switch.

One of the most exciting recent developments in compliant mechanisms (for me) is a mechanical watch regulating mechanism developed by LVMH in cooperation with TU Delft which is made with a single piece of silicon.  A concept watch, the Zenith Defy Lab, was produced in 2017 with this mechanism, which replaced thirty individual components in the regulating mechanism with just two.  A new version of this mechanism has recently gone into regular production in the Zenith Defy Inventor.

I was thinking about building a really low budget  3D-printer. Using out of store threaded axles and nuts you end up getting about 0.5mm of backlash. So what i came up with was using 2 nuts and have them interlinked by a prestressed compliant mechanism ( a spring), all fitted into a tube and encapsuled with grease. Still have to build it but it is possible to build multi-part machines while taking advantages of compliant mechanisms.

"These look just like Vice Grips, but with flexible points instead of axles...."

Um, I'd rather have the Vice Grips tbqh... Axles can be easily repaired/replaced, whereas a bend point is constantly stressed with use, which leads to micro-cracking, cracking/tearing, and eventually irreparable failure. Ever taken a paper clip and bent it back and forth until the wire broke? That's basically what's going on with this prototype tool every time you use it. That means the entire piece has to be a good spring steel, and must undergo a proper manufacturing, hardening, and tempering process. Worse in this particular design, however, is now you have to build it out of differential steels (the spring areas spring steel and the jaws tool steel), and you must also figure out how to temper the spring section to spring temper whilst keeping the jaws as hardened as possible.... Differential materials and differential hardening/tempering processes... Lots of costs associated, when a Vice Grip is just tool steel jaws on heavy stamped/cast mild steel components, with a spring and a screw mechanism... Even simpler and cheaper is a generic slip-joint pliers; two cut/forged/cast lengths of tool steel with jaws and a joint on one end, and a heavy-duty fastener through them as a fulcrum point....

Further, an axle can still function to near-capacity all the way to the point of failure, whereas this particular bend point tool is going to have a wild degradation in performance as it goes from factory new to irreparable failure. With the very first squeeze, you're imparting stress onto a rigid structure, which leads to microscopic breakages of said internal structure which weaken the spring as less tensile strength is possible... Worse yet, as the spring continues to wear over time and use, it will start to "sag", meaning it won't return to its initially designed rested position, but fall somewhere inside its normal range of motion, until it either fails or has sagged to the point it no longer functions as designed. This is typical of firearm magazine springs when the magazine has been left loaded for a long period of time (typically 15-20 years). A good stretch of the spring will fix feeding issues, though the spring is weakened and will deform again (faster this time). At this point, the mag is best used as a spare range mag, because the reliability will be forever questionable.

Don't get me wrong, there are plenty of great applications for bendy parts; tie rods, leaf springs, Russian rear rifle sights, thruster cages, shock mounts for microphones, big fat juicy bass guitar strings, etc. etc. etc... But some things should just be left simple... Like pliers... Cuz pliers shouldn't bend; they should be rigid and impart much squeezing force multiplied by the factor of levers....

I've watched this video a couple of times now, and while his compliant gripper is quite neat, it's got a fatal flaw compared to traditional vice grips; a fixed jaw width.

His compliant gripper may produce a strong force, but it isn't one size fits all. You'd need 10 of his grippers to match the size range of a standard pair of vice grips.

It took me til my 3rd viewing to even... grasp....this simple fact.

Still amazing work.

Don't know why but this reminds me of origami. Once you've formed a two-dimensional piece of paper into a three-dimensional body and you're finished, you can't tell the beginning and the end. Sometimes I imagine the cosmos as an "object" within which many objects are contained, which is folded in itself so many times that it is impossible to see the original folding with the naked eye. If, for example, one would fold a piece of surface the size of a football field in origami manner into a body, it would shrink and at the end be as big as a table tennis table, but look like a hazelnut. 

The flexibility and willingness of the shown material in this video to adapt and at the same time develop great forces is remarkable. The more flexible the less quickly resistors can destroy it. However, I'm a little sceptical about plastic ...

In any case, if a piece of paper were very large, its flat surface could pop up three-dimensional bodies like water lilies on a pond. And yet the two-dimensional would inevitably be connected to the three-dimensional. The "empty surface" would then be the space that holds everything together.

Practical examples of use of compliant mechanisms in everyday products
1. Every shampoo bottle uses a live hinge made by injection molding - very cheap, durable and assembly free.
2. Computer mouse buttons use flexures (those bendy things you see throughout the video). The microswitch inside it has a diaphragm flexure and the top casing flexes when you press on it to transmit the compressive force. Older mouse models had separate distinguishable buttons, now its all one piece.
3. Cable ties have a very small tooth with a flexure that engages a rack. You can often reuse cable ties by disengaging the tooth from the rack using a pin and pull out the rack while holding tooth off the rack with the pin.
4. All plastic components of every product you use has a snap fit for assembly - no requirement of fasteners.
5. Every book uses live hinges (crease where you bend) for opening and closing.
6. Some cheap click type ball point pen (e.g. Bic retractable pen) uses flexures to keep the extended pen nib in its position.
7. Tic tac box uses living hinge for the lid.
8. Volume rockers on your cell phone uses flexures instead of springs to bounce back
9. If you have a wind up pendulum clock, the pendulum is suspended by a flexure for avoiding friction caused by use of a pivot.
10. Snap fit locks for straps in duffle bags/backpacks etc.
11. Some shot microphone mounts uses flexures for vibration isolation.
12. Camera lens covers uses flexures for springs for holding the cover on the lens.
13. Disposable food containers, clamps for IV lines.
14. Paper clips.
15. Foldable plastic forks found in ready to eat noodles have a living hinge in the middle for folding.
16. Leaf springs in vehicle suspension (Thanks to Heartycoffee in the comments for suggestion).
17. Tweezers and forceps (Thanks to randal gibbons in the comments for suggestion)
18. Safety pins (Thanks to DrBrainSol in the comments for suggestion)
19. Accordion-style toilet plunger (Thanks to Gary Young in the comments for suggestion)

 p.s. I will add more to the list later. I love flexures and thank Derek for making a video on compliant mechanisms with Dr.Howell

I hope this helps anyone else who was confused!

In my experience, tools and products that bend rather than turn on a hinge or hook tend to break the fastest. I'm sure that for very specific application where a part is designed with on goal in mind it's great, but I'll take a traditional vice grip.
For example, if anyone has ever tried to repurpose a tic-tac container(for holding tiny screws or small tools) you would know that the flap that keeps the container open or closed is designed to bend, and is also where they tend to fail first. When I've fixed electronics, the number one point of failure in most cases was either a spring or a piece of plastic that was designed to bend or apply tension; i've had to replace the springs in my playstation controller about 5 times. I've also worn glasses all my life, and the part that always breaks first is the nose guards, which are supposed to bend to fit the shape of your nose.
Unless there is some new unknown element discovered that can realign at an atomic level, I can't see how things that are designed to bend are supposed to be a solution to moving parts, which do suffer from mechanical wear, but for the most part provide consistent performance up until the point of failure. I'll take sudden failure over a gradual decline in performance, but that's just my opinion.

The obvious downside is that you can't repair them once they break, and for many of these I could see they would break quite easily if they are misused.  Also failure would be total and instantaneous, where a traditional machine would likely indicate their is a problem before total failure, which you could repair.

Why did he only talk of the positives? Why did he not discuss the cons of these alternatives, like the fact that compliant mechanisms cannot be repaired, only replaced? Or the fact that these mechanisms are built on the principle of having strategic weaknesses? Or the fact that their  operating life when made out of plastic ("at least over a million cycles") is barely equal to or less than the operating life of traditional mechanisms? Or the fact that plastic, likely the only current material that compliant mechanisms could be made at a consumer-level, cannot bear heat like traditional metal pliers of the same price point? I think this video's discussion on their positive impacts on the engineering world is great, but focussing only on what's good about them feels deceptive and makes the title sound like clickbait. Great Production value though, awesome interview with the inventor by the way.

I'm not trying to sound like an ass but that switch test is definitely flawed. Sure you can take a freshly molded/printed plastic switch and it works as he said over a million times without breaking, but that was also in an environmentally controlled room. If it can do all those better than traditional switches then you've got yourself a good design.

Uh this was more like a huge advertising. It didn't address any disadvantages. What about repairing something? You can't replace a screw. But more important: What about aging? Plastic can get recalcitrant (ist this the right word?) and get micro-cracks. Yes they said they did 1 mio cycles with one element but was this verified by a neutral third party? Also you can't just randomly scale an element since it's behavior will change. So this might be interesting for some cases but the video presented it as the best thing for every case and without any scientific scepticism. But as a scientist you shouldn't be fanboying something so easily.
About the satellite thrusters: This whole element was superfluous. There were two motors. You can already archive the movement with just two motors, no need for flexible parts. Actually they just provide another potential point of failure. Especially in space you want to avoid that. That's why they prefer a second thruster (also this provides redundancy). Also space is pretty bad for plastics. So this example was pretty bizarre (to say it mildly).

Leslie Hounsfield designed the engine in his Trojan automobile with with a flexible connecting rod, because in his own mind this was "mechanically correct". I always thought this was funny. The engine was a duplex 2-stroke with two pistons on a Y shaped connecting rod, two small ends for the twin pistons with a common big end. Later copies of this design used a jointed connecting rod, increasing mechanical complexity, manufacturing complexity, weight, etc. Hounsfield's flexible connecting rod seemed like a compromise by conventional wisdom, but he was right - it is "mechanically correct".

I never had any doubt about the performance and simplicity of these mechanisms, but I was always very skeptical about their durability. Take the titanium hinge, for example. I was impressed by the durability of the plastic grabber, but metals are a completely different story. Metals bend and permanently keep their new metallic shape. How many times can that hinge go from -90 to 90 and back until the metallic bonding of the titanium permanently breaks down? More importantly, how does one test its strength once it is in use? I don't want to see that hinge used on an important satellite in outer orbit if we have no way of making sure it is properly maintained. Machines with separate parts show symptoms of particular pieces becoming worn out, but a mechanism made up of only one piece doesn't.

Why are these machines not prone to material fatigue? Seems to me that bending a thin piece of a non-elastic material (like titanium) would quickly cause it to snap after a few bends. Even "bendy" stuff like electrical wiring can be damaged by being twisted a lot.

The mechanics behind the bending thing are neat, and it makes sense in certain applications- but I definitely wouldn't say machines that bend 'are better'. Some machines require rigidity in order to function and it really depends on the application and desired effect. Lubrication and bearings work really really well, and in terms of new tech, a lot of machines are turning to magnetically aligned shafts. (For pumps, compressors, etc.)

I'm pretty curious about how durable these things are... In some applications, like the pincer, I would imagine that the points where stress is concentrated would break or deform beyond a certain resistance to the load they generate. Crushing a piece of chalk? Sure. Chalk is fragile. Crushing your finger? You're going to give before the device does, since your tolerance is much lower. I wonder if a device like the pincer (in ANY material, produced by ANY method) would be suitable for practical applications. Could it replace a vice-grip? How much torque or weight could it endure or support? So many more questions (which is the true reward of this channel anyway, so here we are). :)

I've often wondered about what life could look like on other planets, and about how the mechanical processes of animals could be enacted by different biological processes. Like, why does everything on Earth use flesh and bone and muscles? Could you have an animal that use gears and shafts and electric motors? How would it compare to an Earthly animal of the same size? Well, the more I learn, the more I realize that life on Earth is actually built EXTREMELY well in terms of overall design philosophy.
Take the principles in this video, for example.

Flesh and bone and muscles don't wear out nearly as fast as mechanical components like gears and hinges, don't really need maintenance, don't cause friction by rubbing on each other, don't have any gaps or seams where stuff like rocks or sand could get caught, and can absorb pretty hard impacts without sustaining major damage. With possible exception of bones and teeth, we're entirely built out of compliant mechanisms, from the protein to the ligaments. It's an ingenious structure, and it works really well. I don't know that human science will ever get metal robots that perform as well as human bodies do.

9:22 Aw, look, a centrifugal clutch. Something equivalent, but made with a drum, shoes and two springs, can be found in most mopeds with a CVT or a single gear pulley. It's basically a centrifugal drum brake. Common on chainsaws and lawnmowers. The advantage of having it made of multiple parts is that they don't wear off at the same rate. The springs are almost ethernal, while the padding and the inside of the drum are not. And you only have to change the parts that you need instead of the whole assembly.

Friction is more reliable than flexibility in terms of temperature change. Example: while mechanical wise can be used in extremely low temperatures (For instance: in space) and still hold its maximum force capabilities, flexy-wise will get very fragile and can easily snap upon tension. Finding flexible material which is stable to temperatures can be a challenge and cost consuming.

Unfortunately, I think this principle has been misused
purely for the sake of profit in some cases. Anyone who has experienced a control panel failure on a modern washer or dryer can attest to this. Behind the fascia, the control panel is one large stamped plastic piece that has thinner areas meant to replicate springs or metal leaves, when even one fails, you get to add more plastic to the landfill and shell out $350 for a new panel or get creative with duct tape or other adhesives.

Individual springs would definitely have been a more sustainable & field serviceable solution in this case.

When I had to do this repair, I didn't use duct tape or epoxy but did use flexible plastic sheeting and rubber cement.

I'm curious how these fit on a price-durability graph. If I wanted to replace something bulky/heavy, like a door with a complaint device door, that didn't have hinges, would I be able to get the same (or better) longevity/durability for the same price? I understand that if it was made out of solid metal (like the titanium examples, or the metal clutch in the video), it'd be durable, and I understand that if it was printed out of plastic it would be cheap (as the vice grips are). But I'd love to see data about how they compare as a function of both of those things at the same time. Can they be both cheap and built for every day home use for years. Or is it a trade off of the two at a rate worse than non complaint devices?

To any Engineers out there who think this subject is interesting. I highly recommend getting Dr. Larry Howells book and learning a little about compliant mechanisms (it is less expensive compared to the average college text book). If your institution has a compliant mechanisms class you can gain a fundamental understanding of the limitations and when it is appropriate to use these. You might need to talk to your Mechanical Engineering department as the class name probably won't have it clearly stated. Experience or classes in machine design, machine dynamics, statics/dynamics, and materials are essential for understanding this subject.


Quite a bit of research is being done on this subject currently and still has potential to make big changes in the technological realm!

Being one single part, these designs are harder to fix, but it is possible to make modular plugs for the junctions. Springiness is intrinsic to almost all these designs, also non linear resistance under load is complicated to eliminate. Bolts and oil don't have these problems, and can be lightweight, but more expensive, more likely to jam, not necessarily less strong, you can choose a wider range of materials .

This is nothing new, I don't quite understand what's so special about these? These things are not going to be used in every situation, since what they did not mention in the video is that they are very vulnerable to stress, which limits them to small mechanisms in controlled and contained environment where forces are always predictable. They are also very vulnerable to changes in temperature and depending on material - chemical composition of their surroundings. Anything that affects the material from which it makes enough to deform it, will render the mechanism useless. That's why are used in keyboards and mice, for example, but I highly doubt that clutch disk will survive in an actual car for very long.

Festo built a flexible, pneumatic robot arm that looks like an elephant's trunk. It has basically three separate hose-like air containers alongside each other, which can be expanded and contracted and therefore bend the arm in different directions, similar to a bi-metal strip.
I've also seen door latches made out of a parallelogram-grid-like structure, where the normally "sliding" part was replaced with a part that pivots on another through bending ribs.
I think this has tremendous potential, though materials need to be very durable against fatigue.

Imagine what you could do with this if 3d metal printing had custom alloys and an option to have multiple, separate metals. You could have one metal for it's stiffer properties, and another for it's more elastic properties, then have a transitional alloy between the two allowing for a secure bond of the two dissimilar metals.
I know higher end cnc machines are now coming with additive features that can have custom alloys, but it's basically laser welding metallic powder to a piece, using 2+ powders makes an alloy, and theoretically any alloy is possible with this. Not sure if the same concept would work in 3d printing with sls; it's the same concept, melting metallic powder with a laser, but, as far as I know, sls is much, much weaker in comparison.
Going back to the idea of having a transitional alloy, the laser metal deposition form of additive manufacturing could, in theory, create a perfect gradient with a multi-alloy transition; as the amount of the powder can be controlled, you can go from a blend of 0% metal A and 100% metal B through an alloy gradient that ends at 100% metal A and 0% Metal B. But again, if this has any added benefit, how do you take this tech and add it to much more precise additive manufacturing?

I just thought how awesome it would be if this technology is applied to the automotive industry. Strong, lightweight, highly-tuned single piece suspension systems for example -- nothing that will wear or degrade or leak, and in the worst case that it breaks, the whole unit can be replaced after removing maybe four or five bolts. In aircraft, this could mean single-piece wing and control surfaces (I think NASA already had a concept in the works). Even in the food production industry, single-piece tools are significantly easier to clean and maintain than normal tools that have gaps where food might get stuck and parts that might bind. The possible applications for this technology are endless :)

Often times machine builders do not account for variation.  If you can now add flexibility to compensate for the remaining system variation your system becomes many times more reliable.

When you think about it. The fact that such tech for safely arming nuclear weapons disappears behind the fence is kind of terrifying. I mean I can understand from a national security aspect that countries don’t want the specifics of the designs of their nuclear weapons to fall into foreign governments hands. But the truth of the mater is that a lot of what makes designing nuclear weapons difficult is the refining of the uranium not necessarily the tech in the bomb itself. But it also means that no one on the outside can actually verify what’s actually being used. It’s all fine and good to say that we trust that the best minds, the best intentions, the best everything went into the design. And it’s undoubtably true. But without any ability to verify it also means taking the military’s word for it. There is no equivalent of pubic patents or consumer protection laws or third party safety tests and verifications. No years of patent law and mistakes and trial and error stemming from public accidents and unforeseen mistakes etc. Of course you can’t have such things with nuclear weapons lol. I’m not saying they weren’t tested but that the results of said test are a black box to the public.  So you design them as fault prone as you can, and rest every bit to death. I have no doubt these are probably some of the safest devises ever built. But... I also have to take the military’s word for that, and the fact that they have never gone off by accident. But it does raise concerns imho. For example the safety of aircraft are proven because there are millions of them in the air all the time being punishingly flown all the time and because accidents HAVE happened.

I think this technology combined with the amount of progress we are making with materials science could be really consequential in future engineering.

9:21 the clutch part is also cool, but just like with vice grips the force is transferred through the thin, flexible parts, so it really becomes a material science problem to make a very flexible, but not too flexible and very strong but not too stiff material. Need high tensile strength, but also large range of elastic deformation. Come to think of it; this is the realization of mechanical systems developed prior to invention of hydraulic systems. The force in these mechanical systems is concentrated in smallest parts of the geometry, forcing any future advancements to come as a result of new, better, materials being invented. In hydraulics large force is excreted on large parts of the system while pressure is being kept constant; resulting in ability to use large chunks of weak materials to generate large forces.

BUT... Aren't these systems just a collection of springs, which function as energy storage devices in a macroscopic system with discrete "low" energy states? The flexible materials are a good addition to these systems reducing the need for high precision joints, but ultimately these are two separate things: material science and state machines with discrete energy states. Also, the flexible material part has a downside, strength. The 3d printed vice grips are cool, but the amount of force you can generate in them depends on strength of the flexible part of that geometry. The flexible titanium item IS really cool, but how much distortion can it support when a side load is applied due to change in angle of the top plane? And yes, i guessed the elephant part correctly. How do you design an elephant like that? Easy, you have 3 points to consider, tip of the trunk, top of the trunk and middle of the trunk. Then you design the rest of the geometry (at that point geometry does not even need to be an elephant) such that top and middle support points of the trunk move along the circumferences of 2 circles that are centered at the point where you want the tip of the trunk to remain.

Traditional mechanical engineering has used beam theory with rigid structures to balance out the forces...it was easy to conceptualize, and probably made the math a lot easier too...especially when math was not computer assisted. Even on a “rigid” component, yield point, limit of proportionality, and all that dynamic stuff is a small challenge. I’m willing to bet the math involved for balancing physical forces in compliant structures would not be commercially feasible without computers, which would explain why we didn’t start down that path earlier.

A modern diatonic harmonica can have over 50 pieces- 20 reeds, 20 rivets (some manufacturers use spot welding instead), 2 reed plates, 2 cover plates, 3 (or more, I've seen some with at least 5) reed plate screws, 2 or 4 cover screws (either 2 part chicago bolts or a screw and a nut) and a comb. So, best case, it will have at least 32 pieces, but as many 54 or more.

Back in the day there was a company called Magnus that used plastic. Instead of a reed plate with 10 reeds held on with 10 rivets it molded the reed plates. 2 cover plates, two reed plates, 1 comb. 5 pieces total, glued together.

And harmonicas are flexible machines. Each reed is attached to the reed plate on one end and the other end swings. Reeds are made of phosphor-bronze, brass or stainless steel... interestingly, anecdotally at least, the stainless steel reeds last virtually forever for light players but seem to blow out even quicker for hard players. My theory is that because steel has a small swing range that it can cycle through without fatiguing that light players are staying under that threshold, but harder players are going over it, at which point, as a harder metal, it fatigues faster. (My math isn't good enough to calculate the total arc of the swing along the length to check it against the numbers I've found for the metals though.)

I've gotten in arguments with customizers (a standard 'good' harmonica will run $40 but customizers can get $400) about whether a machine could align the reeds as exactly. My bet was it could, but maybe not in a cost effective way for the industry at its size- more people want wrenches than harmonicas. There is some 'art' to it- you have to get reeds close to choking so that a slight change in technique can choke the reed when you want it to- reeds operate in pairs and to get advanced notes you need to choke one reed. When I see not just how advanced new technologies are getting, but how customizable they are...

It makes me wish I had a degree in computer aided design. :(

Edit-
It should, of course, be pointed out that a million cycles on an instrument is not the same as on a wrench. Those Magnus harmonicas, every one I've tried, is pretty broken while old metal harmonicas sometimes are worth more than new one (lead in old bell brass... some people swear by it). At A 446, an A harmonicas low note could blow through a million swings in no time- 37 minutes. (Although obviously if you played that one note for 37 minutes you'd have pretty boring song, but there are 3 A's above it on a diatonic A harp, each with 2x the frequency, so the top one would be less than 10 minutes, and there are higher harps.)

It would have been nice if he would have shown just how precise the movement was. for example with the elephant, it looked like the round hole in the trunk was placed concentric with the center of rotation, he should have placed a dial indicator in there just to show how little deviation their was because it is difficult to see on camera. what is crazy is that to get the same kind of zero backlash with traditional machined parts requires very precisely ground pins and machined holes which depending on the level of precision required can get very expensive. However the strength is another very important consideration, How strong would that Thin titanium hinge be compared to a traditional ceramic deep grove ball bearing of similar size and weight. further more the titanium hinge looked like it would have been very poor with any potential axial loading, though I am not sure if that would be an important consideration considering spacecraft tend to not change attitude too quickly like you can in kerbal space program😁 so axial loading might not be that important. One thing to note is that design of the hinge would also act as a shock absorber at the same time as performing the job of a bearing and return spring, which is important if you want to survive the vibrations during launch, so effectively it takes the job of three different entire subsystems all with one part. And the same goes for the engine gimbal which I had no idea you could even make out of one part like this, though you still have the motors as separate parts (for now). Absolutely amazing! Your videos are very interesting and comprehensible. This one was too, but it left me with questions. Quite a lot of them actually.

My understanding is you wanted to explain the main topic vividly. The examples you used for that did their job - I feel I know the basic principles of compliant mechanisms and how they can be utilized. I also know, I have a huge gap in understanding how the examples work:
How are the chips made, and what are they needed for?
How is the titanium so bendy? Is it because of the large surface, i.e. the sum of many slight deviations?
What other requirements exist for the thrusters? Why is this solution good/the best?
What is the benefit of using a clutch? Why is it a benefit?
Does the laser hit the cog all the time, or just under special circumstances? Why does the cog have to rotate with 2 Hz? What compels the cog to rotate?

I'm sure I could fill at least some of these burning questions in my brain with a trip down a research rabbit hole. If your intention was to encourage self-motivated learning - well done!

Schizophrenia

Delusions. These are false beliefs that are not based in reality. For example, you think that you're being harmed or harassed; certain gestures or comments are directed at you; you have exceptional ability or fame; another person is in love with you; or a major catastrophe is about to occur. Delusions occur in most people with schizophrenia.

Hallucinations. These usually involve seeing or hearing things that don't exist. Yet for the person with schizophrenia, they have the full force and impact of a normal experience. Hallucinations can be in any of the senses, but hearing voices is the most common hallucination.

Disorganized thinking (speech). Disorganized thinking is inferred from disorganized speech. Effective communication can be impaired, and answers to questions may be partially or completely unrelated. Rarely, speech may include putting together meaningless words that can't be understood, sometimes known as word salad.

Extremely disorganized or abnormal motor behavior. This may show in a number of ways, from childlike silliness to unpredictable agitation. Behavior isn't focused on a goal, so it's hard to do tasks. Behavior can include resistance to instructions, inappropriate or bizarre posture, a complete lack of response, or useless and excessive movement.

8:13 as far as I know, alloy elements always stiffen the material because they bring tension on a microscopic level take iron (Fe) for an example the pure stuff which you won't entcounter in your daily life besides in electroni8cal components. The raw material is fairly soft but if you only add a little bit of carbon intentionally or not, in very small portions we are talking under 0,8% by mass. Those carbon atoms will set them self between the iron Kristal structure or even displace a Fe atom. those are 0-Dimensional Errors in the Kristal structure of materials. And it gets up Volume defects which are errors of the 3d Dimension I could keep on talking but basically, the purer an Element is the more flexible it is and if you have more alloy elements the more brittle it gets. Think of gold 24 carats (99.99%Au) is very soft and 18 carat is much harder and brittle. (But copper and gold and silver get work hardened unlike other materials they become soft when you heat them and fastly cool them down after) As you can see I really like MaterialScience and it is a topic id love to see you make a video about because it brings so much to the table and there are so many interesting things to learn.

Plastic channel locks would not be cheaper than metal ones. Metal is nether rare nor expensive to process. We have been making steel continuously on an industrial scale for over one hundred years now. Plastic channel locks would require new factories, petrochemicals that are worse for the environment than the slag steel mills produce, and they will lose elasticity at the flex point over time and simply break. Metal channel locks can last a lifetime if you take care of them. And metal is more recyclable and will, left to it's own devices, return to the earth as iron oxide. Plastic hangs around potentially forever, cannot be continuously recycled, and left to it's own devices could become an environmental hazard. Plastic bottles are menace enough. We don't need broken plastic tools added to the mix.
